skill.name: slack-gif-creator
skill.description: Knowledge and utilities for creating animated GIFs optimized for Slack. Provides constraints, validation tools, and animation concepts. Use when users request animated GIFs for Slack like "make me a GIF of X doing Y for Slack."
skill.summary: Knowledge and utilities for creating animated GIFs optimized for Slack. Provides constraints, valida...
skill.author: anthropics

security_audit.summary: Official skill from Anthropic repository. Uses standard Python libraries (PIL, imageio, numpy) for image processing. No network access, no subprocess calls, no environment variable access.

content.value_statement: Creating animated GIFs for Slack requires specific dimensions, color limits, and frame rates to display properly. This skill provides tools to build GIFs that meet Slack requirements with smooth easing functions and visual effects.
actual_capabilities: Build GIFs programmatically using PIL ImageDraw primitives for shapes, text, and gradients
Validate GIF dimensions and file size against Slack emoji (128x128) and message (480x480) requirements
Apply easing functions (bounce, elastic, back) for natural animation motion
Optimize GIF files with color quantization, duplicate frame removal, and automatic resizing
Create animation effects including pulse, bounce, shake, spin, fade, and particle bursts
Generate gradient backgrounds and draw circles, stars, polygons, and text on frames
limitations: Does not provide pre-made animation templates or a library of built-in graphics
Does not render emoji fonts reliably across different platforms
User must write animation logic using provided utilities rather than using pre-built effects
Output GIF files are saved to disk by the calling code; the skill does not manage file output directly

use_cases.title: Custom emoji GIFs
use_cases.description: Create animated emoji reactions sized 128x128 pixels with optimized file size for team communication.

use_cases.title: Micro-animations
use_cases.description: Design small animated illustrations for feature announcements, onboarding flows, and UI feedback moments.

use_cases.title: Celebration graphics
use_cases.description: Generate animated celebration GIFs for deployments, milestones, and achievements shared in team channels.

prompt_templates.title: Basic emoji GIF
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a bouncing star GIF sized 128x128 pixels with 10 frames at 15 fps. Use yellow fill and a dark outline.

prompt_templates.title: Gradient animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pulsing circle GIF sized 480x480 with 24 frames. Use a gradient background from blue to purple and apply ease_out_cubic for smooth scaling.

prompt_templates.title: Slack-optimized export
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an animated GIF for Slack message use, then validate it meets the 480x480 dimension requirement and check if the file size is under 128KB.

prompt_templates.title: Particle effect
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an explosion effect with particles radiating outward from the center. Use fade-out opacity, gravity effects on particles, and elastic ease_out for natural motion. Optimize for emoji size.

output_examples.input: Create a simple animated heart GIF for Slack emoji
output: Generated 128x128 heart GIF with pulsing animation
24 frames at 15 fps using ease_in_out_cubic easing
Red fill (#E91E63) with dark red outline
File size: 18 KB - optimized for Slack emoji upload

best_practices: Use the validate_gif function to verify dimensions before export; emoji GIFs should be exactly 128x128 pixels
Apply easing functions instead of linear motion for natural, polished animations that feel professional
Limit colors to 48-128 and frames to 12-24 for smaller file sizes that load quickly in Slack channels
anti_patterns: Using linear easing for all animations creates mechanical-looking motion that lacks visual appeal
Ignoring file size limits results in GIFs that fail to upload or load slowly in Slack
Drawing complex graphics frame-by-frame without using easing functions produces jerky, choppy animation

faq.question: What dimensions should I use for Slack emoji GIFs?
faq.answer: Slack emoji GIFs work best at 128x128 pixels. Message GIFs can be up to 480x480 pixels with an aspect ratio under 2.0.

faq.question: How many frames should my GIF have?
faq.answer: Keep emoji GIFs around 12 frames (under 3 seconds) and message GIFs under 30 frames. Use lower FPS (10-15) to reduce file size.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill works with Claude, Claude Code, and Codex for creating GIFs through conversation. Import the modules and build frames programmatically.

faq.question: Is user-uploaded image data stored or processed externally?
faq.answer: No. All image processing happens locally using PIL and numpy. No data is sent to external services or stored beyond the current session.

faq.question: Why does my GIF have a large file size?
faq.answer: Large file sizes result from high frame counts, many colors, or large dimensions. Use fewer frames (10-15), limit colors to 48, and resize to 128x128 for emoji GIFs.

faq.question: How does this skill compare to online GIF makers?
faq.answer: This skill provides programmatic control for consistent, reproducible GIFs through code. Online tools offer templates but lack customization and integration with AI workflows.
